page.title: 06Cockfield Hall Farm.
page.content: Cockfield Hall is definitely the oldest dwelling in the area,being at least 700 years old.It was built by a Frenchman named Vansour and is a listed building which means that it cannot be structurally altered.It is situated on the Eastern outskirts of the village,behind the church. Cockfield Hall used to be part of Strathmore Estate,belonging at one time to the Earl of Glamis,who was grandfather to Queen Elizabeth IInd. The farm is now owned by Mr and Mrs Bainbridge.They bought it from the Strathmore Estate in 1950,but the Bainbridges have farmed this land for 202 years,the early years as tenants. The house and farm buildings are all stone built and it is interesting to see the solid stone walls which are 3 ft.thick.All the doorways, even the farm buildings.
